content: I've come across an instance that takes the intersection of a finset and a regular set using ↓∩ , and I would like to either show implicitly that that itself is a finset, or use a separate operation that does this coerced intersection over Finsets instead.

I've always used Finset.filter for this, and we now have notation to make that even easier. So if s is your finset and t is your set, you can say {x \in s | x \in t}, which will be the finset you're talking about (as a Finset). And simp knows that the elements of this are what they should be!
Tristan Figueroa-Reid has marked this topic as resolved.
